|Hayasa-Hittite war
(14th century BC)
|Hayasa-Azzi
|Hittitie Empire
|Hayasan defeat
* The initial success of Hayasa-Azzi and other Hittite enemies. The Azzi forces took the Hittite capital Samuha.
* Hattusa regrouped, and the battle near Kumaha ended most probably in a Hittite victory.
* Hayasa-Azzi was most probably turned into a Hittite vassal state.
* A prisoner exchange happened between two countries.
* Hayasan king Mariya married a Hittite princess.
|-
|Anniya's invasion of Hittite Empire
(End of the 14 century BC)
|Hayasa-Azzi
|Hittite Empire
|Hayasan defeat
* Hayasan king Anniya invaded the bordering Hittite regions of Dankuwa and Upper Land, sacked the area, and took captives.
* In the 9th year of the war, Hittite commander Nuwanza won a major victory in the battle of Ganuvara and reconquered the Upper Land.
* In the tenth year of the war, Hayasa was defeated and became a Hittite vassal state.

|Armenian victory
* Gordyene, Atropatene, Osroene, Adiabene, Mygdonia, Commogene Iberia, and Albania became Armenian vassals.
* Tigranes the Great took the title of King of Kings from the Parthians.
* Sophene, the Seleucid Empire, and Cilicia were annexed.
* Judea and Nabathea accepted Armenian suzerainty.
* Armenian and Pontic forces were forced to withdraw from Cappadocia by Sulla.

|Third Mithridatic war
(73-63 BC)
|Kingdom of Pontus (73-63 BC)

kingdom of Iberia (69-65 BC)
Kingdom of Albania(69-65 BC)
|Roman Republic (73-63 BC)
Parthian Empire(66 BC)
|Defeat of Pontus and Armenia
* Refusing to give up Mithridates VI of Rome, Armenia suffered a major defeat in Tigranocerta, with the city being sacked
* The Armenian army suffered another defeat near Artaxata; however, the victory didn't give Lucullus any strategic advantage.
* After besieging Nisibis, Lucullus suffered defeat from Armenian-Pontic forces at the battle of Zela. Mithridates temporarily restored his reign in Pontus, and Tigranes occupied and sacked Cappadocia
* Lucullus was replaced by Pompey, who defeated Mithridates and persuaded Parthia to invade Armenia
* Armenia surrendered
* Armenia accepted Roman suzerainty.
* Armenia lost all its conquests to Rome and Parthia except for Gordyene and Armenian Mesopotamia.
* Tigranes kept the title of King of Kings
* Sophene was restored as a Roman client kingdom with Tigranes's son Tirgan Junior as king. Later reintegrated with Armenia
* Armenia had to pay reparations to Rome, which was done by the treasury of Sophene
